Award.AwardTitle: Dynamic Behavior Structure and Reactivity of Selfassembled Carbanionic Species
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award from the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms Program supports the work of Professor Gideon A. Fraenkel of Ohio State University on the structure and fast equilibrium dynamic behavior of carbanions and carbanionic species. In the work particular organolithium compounds are prepared which are designed to reveal in simple fashion specific aspects of structure and dynamic behavior. Structures are investigated using NMR, X-ray crystallography and DFT modeling. The kinetics and mechanisms of fast molecular reorganization processes at equilibrium are revealed from NMR line shape analysis. These processes may include the dynamics of carbanionic inversion, carbon-lithium bond and ligand lithium bond, exchange respectively and aggregate interconversion. Aspects of structure of interest include the effect on degree of conjugation within the carbanion due to orientation of anion and cation. These studies will be applied to lithium salts of dihydropyridines. Other studies involve a new possible preparation of ladder polymers.

The broader aspects of this program involve opportunities to train undergraduates including women and members of underrepresented minorities in a variety of sophisticated techniques which will help them prepare for careers in industry or academia. Undergraduates have always been involved in the research. There is extensive collaboration with groups around the world, within the Chemistry department here at Ohio State University and in industry on dynamic NMR problems and as well as on chemistry developed by the Fraenkel group. All these interactions provide excellent contacts for members of the group.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Ourcomes Report for the General Public

We are interested in carbanions (organic molecules in which one of the carbons bears a negative charge, one of three important intermdiates in chemical reactions. However carbanions are rarely free, rather they come as the negative or partially negative part of some organometallic compound, that is a compound of carbon and hydrogen which incorporates a bond or a partial bond between carbon and some metal. More often than not the metal is coordinated to an ether or an amine, often the solvent. Organolithium compounds (call them RLI species) were chosen as model systems and for the simplicity of their preparation. Altogether we used the methods of organic synthesis, NMR (Nuclear Magnetic Resonance), X-ray crystallography which gives a picture of a molecule's three dimensional structure and quantum mechanical calculations. Our molecules were specifically designed to reveal in simple fashion, in their physical behavior, specific aspects of carbanion behavior.. These include the dynamics of carbanion inversion (turning inside out at carbon bonded to metal), the mutual exchange of lithiums and ligands between two RLi species and rotation around bonds. We determined the rates of these fast molecular reorganizations and hence their kinetics and mechanisms using our methods of dynamic NMR. By mechanism we mean the description as to how a reorganization takes place. For example using carbon-13 NMR (C-13 NMR) we discovered. that many RLi species are aggregated in solution, that is stuck together in groups of twp, four or six. This was revealed by splittings in the C-13 NMR of carbon-13 bonded to lithium. These splittings averaged with increasing temperature as a result of increasing rates of mutual exchange of lithiums beteen RLi species. NMR line shape analysis provided the rates of lithium exchange. Thus not only could we determine the structure of an RLi species but we could fish out the rates of the different reorganization processes and their mechanisms.. The results of these sorts of basic studies  turned out to be extremely helpful to organic chemists who use RLi species extensively in synthesis of complex molecules

In a practical application of our research, using RLi chemistry we made what is called "high vinyl polybutadienc" That is a long hydrocarbon chain with a vinyl group attached to every third carbon in the chain. A vinyl group consists of a carbon carbon double bond with two hydrogens bonded to one carbon and one hydrogen at the other carbon. The latter carbon is attached to the chain. We added hydrogen to the vinyl groups and thus made a polymer, fully alkane, with an ethyl group attached to every third carbon in the chain. This polymer is now used to make aircraft tires. In the past, bursting of aircraft tires when a plane hit the runway was not uncommon with resulting injured passengers, even deaths, not to mention damage to the aircraft. Now with our new polymer aircraft tires rarely burst when a plane lands. The cost of tragedy averted thanks to our polymer vastly exceeds all that was ever spent by the NSF on behalf of our research. Note how basic research, which importantly extends knowledge and insight, is more likely to have practical benefits than parallel applied studied studies directed at specific pproblems.

Many undergraduates have been involved in our research. The problems we work on are particularly suitable for undergraduate research since the starting materials are easily made and NMR studies can be initiated early on in the project. These early NMR results convey important clues as to whether the project is worthy of further study. With undergraduates in the lab the PI has been able to advise them of opportunities in science. Several of our students have gone on to become creative productive scientists and physicians.

We hare gratef...

Several of our students have gone on to become creative productive scientists and physicians.
